natural problem: Bill is sent to a donut shop to purchase exactly six donuts. If the shop has four kinds of donuts and Bill is to get at least one of each kind, how many combinations will satisfy Bill's order requirements?
natural solution: Bill is required to get at least 1 of each of the 4 kinds. Once he has done that, he has two donuts left to buy with no restrictions. He can do this by buying 2 of the same kind, which can be done in 4 ways, or he can do this by buying two donuts which are different kinds.

If he buys donuts of different kinds, there are 4 options for the type of the first donut and 3 options for the second donut, but since the order that he selects them in doesn't matter we need to divide by two to get to a final count of $\dfrac{4\cdot3}{2}=6$ ways to buy two distinct donuts.
This gives us a total of $6+4=10$ ways to buy the last 2 donuts once he has bought one of each kind, so $\boxed{10}$ is our answer.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes combinations :: nat and donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 6"
and h1 : "combinations = 4"
and h2 : "donuts div combinations \<ge> 1"
shows  "combinations = 10"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Bill is sent to a donut shop to purchase exactly six donuts. If the shop has four kinds of donuts and Bill is to get at least one of each kind, how many combinations will satisfy Bill's order requirements? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 Bill is required to get at least 1 of each of the 4 kinds. Once he has done that, he has two donuts left to buy with no restrictions. He can do this by buying 2 of the same kind, which can be done in 4 ways, or he can do this by buying two donuts which are different kinds.
 If he buys donuts of different kinds, there are 4 options for the type of the first donut and 3 options for the second donut, but since the order that he selects them in doesn't matter we need to divide by two to get to a final count of $\dfrac{4\cdot3}{2}=6$ ways to buy two distinct donuts.
 This gives us a total of $6+4=10$ ways to buy the last 2 donuts once he has bought one of each kind, so $\boxed{10}$ is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes combinations :: nat and donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 6"
and h1 : "combinations = 4"
and h2 : "donuts div combinations \<ge> 1"
shows  "combinations = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Assume that there are 6 donuts and 4 different combinations to choose from. If each combination can have at least one donut, what is the total number of combinations? The final answer is 10.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> \<exists>donut_combinations. donut_combinations = (6 choose n)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. (6 choose n)) {1..4} = 10"

 ### Proof

 This gives us a total of $6+4=10$ ways to buy the last 2 donuts once he has bought one of each kind, so $\boxed{10}$ is our answer.

theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> \<exists>donut_combinations. donut_combinations = (6 choose n)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>n. (6 choose n)) {1..4} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that there are 4 types of donuts, find the total number of combinations you can make by choosing 1 to 4 types of donuts out of 6 types. The final answer is 10.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes donuts :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "donuts 1 \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "donuts 2 \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "donuts 3 \<ge> 1"
and h3 : "donuts 4 \<ge> 1"
and h4 : "donuts 1 + donuts 2 + donuts 3 + donuts 4 = 6"
shows  "card {donuts. donuts 1 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 2 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 3 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 4 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 1 + donuts 2 + donuts 3 + donuts 4 = 6} = 10"
a_2.formal solution:

 This gives us a total of $6+4=10$ ways to buy the last 2 donuts once he has bought one of each kind, so $\boxed{10}$ is our answer.
 *)

fixes donuts :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "donuts 1 \<ge> 1"

shows  "card {donuts. donuts 1 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 2 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 3 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 4 \<ge> 1 \<and> donuts 1 + donuts 2 + donuts 3 + donuts 4 = 6} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that you have 4 types of donuts, each of which you have at least one, and the total number of donuts is 6, how many different ways can you distribute the donuts? The final answer is 10.

a_3.formal problem:
definition "donuts = {1::nat, 2, 3, 4}"
definition "orders = {f. f \<in> donuts \<rightarrow>\<^sub>E {1..6} \<and> sum f donuts = 6 \<and> (\<forall>d\<in>donuts. f d \<ge> 1)}"

theorem "card orders = 10"
  oops

end

a_3.informal problem: Four friends are ordering donuts. Each person orders at least one donut, and there are six donuts in total. In how many ways can the four friends order the donuts? The final answer is 10.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 6"
and h1 : "card {d :: nat. d \<le> 4} = 4"
and h2 : "card {d :: nat. d \<le> donuts} = donuts"
shows  "n_subsets 4 donuts = 10"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 6"
and h1 : "card {d :: nat. d \<le> 4} = 4"
and h2 : "card {d :: nat. d \<le> donuts} = donuts"
shows  "n_subsets 4 donuts = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If there are 6 donuts, how many ways can you choose 4 donuts? The final answer is 10 ways.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 4"
and h1 : "combinations = (\<Sum>i=1..donuts. i choose 6)"
shows  "combinations = 10"
a_5.formal solution:

theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 4"

a_5.informal problem: Given that there are 4 donuts, find the sum of all the combinations of choosing 6 donuts at a time for each of the 4 donuts. The final answer is 10.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes donuts :: "nat set"
and kinds :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card kinds = 4"
and h1 : "card donuts = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> kind. kind \<in> kinds \<longrightarrow> card {donut \<in> donuts. donut = kind} \<ge> 1"
shows  "card {combos. combos \<subseteq> donuts \<and> card combos = 6} = 10"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 This gives us a total of $6+4=10$ ways to buy the last 2 donuts once he has bought one of each kind, so $\boxed{10}$ is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes donuts :: "nat set"
and kinds :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "card kinds = 4"
and h1 : "card donuts = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> kind. kind \<in> kinds \<longrightarrow> card {donut \<in> donuts. donut = kind} \<ge> 1"
shows  "card {combos. combos \<subseteq> donuts \<and> card combos = 6} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A donut shop offers 4 kinds of donuts. If you want to buy 6 donuts and at least one of each kind must be included, how many different combinations can you have? The final answer is 10.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 6"
and h1 : "\<exists>a b c d. a + b + c + d = donuts \<and> a \<ge> 1 \<and> b \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<ge> 1 \<and> d \<ge> 1"
shows  "card {(a,b,c,d) |a b c d. a + b + c + d = donuts \<and> a \<ge> 1 \<and> b \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<ge> 1 \<and> d \<ge> 1} = 10"
a_7.formal solution:

 *)

theorem
fixes donuts :: nat
assumes h0 : "donuts = 6"
and h1 : "\<exists>a b c d. a + b + c + d = donuts \<and> a \<ge> 1 \<and> b \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<ge> 1 \<and> d \<ge> 1"
shows  "card {(a,b,c,d) |a b c d. a + b + c + d = donuts \<and> a \<ge> 1 \<and> b \<ge> 1 \<and> c \<ge> 1 \<and> d \<ge> 1} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: How many ways can 6 donuts be divided between 4 people, if each person must get at least one donut? The final answer is 10.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes combinations :: nat
assumes h0 : "combinations = 10"
shows  "\<exists> d1 d2 d3 d4. d1 + d2 + d3 + d4 = 6 \<and> d1 \<ge> 1 \<and> d2 \<ge> 1 \<and> d3 \<ge> 1 \<and> d4 \<ge> 1"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Bill is sent to a donut shop to purchase exactly six donuts. If the shop has four kinds of donuts and Bill is to get at least one of each kind, how many combinations will satisfy Bill's order requirements? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 Bill is required to get at least 1 of each of the 4 kinds. Once he has done that, he has two donuts left to buy with no restrictions. He can do this by buying 2 of the same kind, which can be done in 4 ways, or he can do this by buying two donuts which are different kinds.

 This gives us a total of $6+4=10$ ways to buy the last 2 donuts once he has bought one of each kind, so $\boxed{10}$ is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes combinations :: nat
assumes h0 : "combinations = 10"
shows  "\<exists> d1 d2 d3 d4. d1 + d2 + d3 + d4 = 6 \<and> d1 \<ge> 1 \<and> d2 \<ge> 1 \<and> d3 \<ge> 1 \<and> d4 \<ge> 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: "Find four whole numbers d1, d2, d3 and d4, each greater than or equal to 1, such that their sum equals 6."

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bill_donuts :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> bill_donuts i \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "sum bill_donuts {1..4} = 6"
shows  "card {donuts. donuts \<in> {1..4} --> nat & (sum donuts {1..4} = 6) & (\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> donuts i \<ge> 1)} = 10"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Bill is sent to a donut shop to purchase exactly six donuts. If the shop has four kinds of donuts and Bill is to get at least one of each kind, how many combinations will satisfy Bill's order requirements? The final Answer is 10
 ### Proof
 Bill is required to get at least 1 of each of the 4 kinds. Once he has done that, he has two donuts left to buy with no restrictions. He can do this by buying 2 of the same kind, which can be done in 4 ways, or he can do this by buying two donuts which are different kinds.
 If he buys donuts of different kinds, there are 4 options for the type of the first donut and 3 options for the second donut, but since the order that he selects them in doesn't matter we need to divide by two to get to a final count of $\dfrac{4\cdot3}{2}=6$ ways to buy two distinct donuts.
 This gives us a total of $6+4=10$ ways to buy the last 2 donuts once he has bought one of each kind, so $\boxed{10}$ is our answer.
 *)

theorem
fixes bill_donuts :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> bill_donuts i \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "sum bill_donuts {1..4} = 6"
shows  "card {donuts. donuts \<in> {1..4} --> nat & (sum donuts {1..4} = 6) & (\<forall> i. 1 \<le> i \<and> i \<le> 4 \<longrightarrow> donuts i \<ge> 1)} = 10"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Bill buys donuts over 4 days. On each day, he buys at least one donut. In total, he buys 6 donuts over the 4 days. How many different combinations of donuts could he have bought over the 4 days? The final answer is 10.
